author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Rachel Maddow Will Return to Nightly Shows on MSNBC for Trump’s First 100 Days
description: The cable news network rejiggers its prime-time lineup ahead of Donald Trump’s second stint in the White House.
content: Rachel Maddow pared back her on-air schedule during President Biden’s time in office, reducing her popular prime-time program on MSNBC to once a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: Supreme Court Clears a Path for Climate Lawsuits to Proceed
description: The high court declined to hear a challenge to a major case in which Honolulu is suing energy companies over climate change.
content: In a decision widely seen as benefiting climate activists, the Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear a challenge to a lawsuit filed by Honolulu against oil companies over their role in global warming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Mac
title: After Attacking L.A. Wildfire Response, Elon Musk Sends His Products to Help
description: The world’s richest person has stoked outrage about the devastating wildfires and efforts to tackle them. On Sunday, he said he would help provide internet access to areas in need in Los Angeles.
content: Elon Musk has a history of involving himself, often controversially, in crises. In recent years, the billionaire has promised to fund fixes to contaminated water at homes in Flint, Mich., developed a submarine to rescue trapped children from a submerged cave in Thailand (it wasn’t used) and experimented with building ventilators for Covid patients during the early stages of the coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Group of Experts Says R.F.K. Jr. Would ‘Significantly Undermine’ Public Health
description: A coalition opposing the nominee for health secretary includes faculty members from leading U.S. academic institutions, including public health schools at Yale and Harvard.
content: A new national coalition of health professionals and scientists, mobilizing to oppose Senate confirmation of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to be the United States’ next health secretary, released a public letter on Monday warning that his “unfounded, fringe beliefs could significantly undermine public health practices across the country and around the world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: Martin Karplus, Chemist Who Made Early Computers a Tool, Dies at 94
description: Proving skeptics wrong, he shared a Nobel Prize in 2013 for using computers to better understand chemical reactions and biological processes.
content: Martin Karplus, a Nobel Prize-winning theoretical chemist who used computers to model how complex systems change during chemical reactions, a process that has led to advances in the understanding of biological processes, died on Dec. 28 at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 11, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Jan. 11, 2025.
content: An article on Friday about the Buffalo Bills’ window for winning in the short- and long-term misstated when the Detroit Lions clinched the N.F.C.’s top playoff seed. It was Sunday night, not Monday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
title: Judge Allows Release of Half of Special Counsel’s Report on Trump Cases
description: Judge Aileen M. Cannon, who dismissed the classified documents case, blocked a volume about that matter from being shown to Congress but allowed the release of a volume about the election case.
content: A federal judge in Florida cleared the way on Monday for the Justice Department to soon release a portion of a report written by the special counsel, Jack Smith, detailing the decisions he made in charging President-elect Donald J. Trump with plotting to overturn his loss in the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Michael Gold
title: Who’s Performing at Trump’s Inauguration?
description: Carrie Underwood will sing “America the Beautiful” at the second inauguration of Donald J. Trump.
content: The singer Carrie Underwood said Monday that she would perform next week at President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inauguration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Trump’s Inaugural Celebration Will Kick Off at His Golf Club in Virginia
description: The president-elect is set to arrive in the Washington area on Saturday and begin a series of events that includes a party at Trump National Golf Club and a rally at Capital One Arena.
content: President-elect Donald J. Trump will kick off a series of inaugural events with a party for roughly 500 donors, friends and other supporters at his golf club in Sterling, Va., on Saturday, according to officials with the inaugural committee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Will Artificial Intelligence Replace Us or Empower Us?
description: People will need a lot more education to be able to harness A.I. rather than be elbowed aside.
content: I took three Waymo rides this month while in San Francisco for an economics conference. The smooth trips made for a haunting vision of the potential future of artificial intelligence. Inside the cabs, there was gentle New Age music and no one in the driver’s seat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Two Cool Ways to Keep Heads Warm
description: Artfully layered headgear enhanced a duo’s style.
content: Nathalie Joseph, left, and Christel Jean-Pierre were scouting locations for a photo shoot in Washington Square Park on a Saturday in December when they caught my eye with their layered head gear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French, Katherine Miller and Vishakha Darbha
title: David French on the Case for Banning TikTok
description: The Opinion columnist explains the threat to national security posed by the app’s Chinese ownership.
content: The Supreme Court seems ready to uphold the law that would ban TikTok unless the app’s Chinese parent company, ByteDance, sells it to a U.S. buyer. The Opinion columnist David French talks with the politics editor Katherine Miller about why he believes the app poses a unique threat to U.S. security.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Stanley-Becker
title: Europe Wasn’t Built to Be Like This
description: Schengen is now a symbol of the migration crisis driving the backlash against globalization and the ascendance of illiberalism.
content: When I crossed a bridge spanning the Rhine last year, a checkpoint blocked the route between France and Germany, on the Pont de l’Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Try a Little Tenderness
description: Stories of people who try a radical approach to solving their problems.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: A Blue Trench and a Scarf Bonnet
description: Vibrant outerwear set a wintry outfit apart.
content: In a cobalt-blue trench coat, Carlie Mahnke, 27, was a bright sight amid the countless people in dark winter jackets walking on West 43rd Street in Midtown Manhattan on a Friday in December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Hopkins Legaspi
title: How Healthy Is Citrus Fruit?
description: Its immune-boosting vitamin C is only part of the story.
content: Oranges, grapefruits and the other members of the citrus family are at their sweetest and juiciest in winter, when weather conditions are ideal for them to ripen. And they’re bursting with nutrients that support your immune system and help your body heal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Here’s How Senate Confirmation Works for Trump’s Cabinet
description: The Senate’s role of “advice and consent” is a marathon of meetings and paperwork.
content: Some of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s selections for cabinet positions are set to begin confirmation hearings this week, paving the way for them to serve in their roles around the start of his administration. But the hearings — the most public part of the confirmation process — are just one feature of a complicated vetting of those hoping to run federal agencies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Moore
title: An Illustrator Dies, His Last Book Unfinished. In Steps His Son.
description: A beloved illustrator died in the middle of a project. His son, who had been drifting away from art for years, was given the chance to finish the work.
content: Charles Santore was in the middle of illustrating the children’s book he did not know would be his last when he began to feel weak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: In L.A., the Heartache of Being Home
description: Tejal Rao, a Times food critic who lives in Los Angeles, explores the fleeting nature of safety after the fires.
content: All week, I’ve been reassuring friends and family across the world checking in over texts, DMs and WhatsApp messages with this: We’re safe <3. But right now in Los Angeles, safety is a provisional state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By R.O. Kwon
title: Sex, Drugs and Clubbing Are a Means of Escape for This ‘Good Girl’
description: Aria Aber’s exciting debut novel finds the daughter of an Afghan refugee sidestepping disapproval and racism as she dives into Berlin’s nightworld.
content: Toward the start of “Good Girl,” Aria Aber’s exhilarating debut novel, 18-year-old Nila returns home to Berlin from an exclusive boarding school, enrolls in college, then pitches herself into “the glittery, destructive underworld” of the city. “I was ravaged by the hunger to ruin my life,” Nila says, and proceeds, with formidable energy, to try to fulfill her appetite for self-destruction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: For Los Angeles, Fires Ramp Up Difficulty of Hosting 2028 Summer Games
description: Rebuilding areas ravaged by wildfires will present a daunting challenge, but the flip side could be the “compelling image of a city emerging from the ashes.”
content: For seven years, the promise of the 2028 Summer Olympics has shimmered on the horizon as a source of pride and celebration for Los Angeles. There were concerns: the homelessness crisis, cost overruns, comparisons with the successful Games last year in Paris. But for the most part, 2028 held out the hope of delivering as much of a boost for the region’s economy and international image as the Olympics of 1984.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heller McAlpin
title: A Heartbreaking Novel of Addiction, Written With Compassion and Wit
description: In John Dufresne’s new book, “My Darling Boy,” a retired journalist races to rescue his son from the painful grip of opioids.
content: John Dufresne, known for his dark, rollicking novels laced with wit, grit, compassion and offbeat characters, has written an improbably entertaining book on opioid addiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Eaton Fire Victims Sue Southern California Edison
description: Altadena residents said in separate lawsuits that the utility’s electrical equipment had sparked the fire, which grew to consume 14,000 acres.
content: Residents of Altadena, Calif., who lost property in the Eaton fire filed lawsuits against Southern California Edison on Monday, saying that the utility’s electrical equipment had sparked the blaze.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis’ Autobiography, ‘Hope,’ Arrives in Bookstores
description: The book, which was six years in the making, vividly recreates Francis’ childhood in Buenos Aires but offers few new insights into his papacy.
content: “I like punctuality, it’s a virtue I have learned to appreciate,” Pope Francis writes in the fifth chapter of his autobiography, to be published on Tuesday in 18 languages, adding that he considers it “a sign of good manners and respect, to arrive promptly.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: Want to Score Cheap Travel This Year? Here’s When to Buy.
description: Mark your calendar to take advantage of sales, slow periods and the best travel deals.
content: Traveling off-season, booking early, playing with flexible dates and going somewhere off the beaten path are tried-and-true budget travel strategies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Review: A Dance That Wonders ‘What Will Happen to Us?’
description: Miguel Gutierrez’s “Super Nothing” at New York Live Arts asks how dance can confront the steady stream of life’s troubles.
content: The title of Miguel Gutierrez’s latest work, “Super Nothing,” reaches toward opposite ends of a spectrum, as if pulling itself apart: over-full and empty, momentous and insignificant. It evokes the contradictions of a life in dance — that medium which requires so much effort for so little material reward — and of being alive in general. In a recent conversation with Bill T. Jones, the artistic director of New York Live Arts, where “Super Nothing” opened on Sunday, Gutierrez noted that a dance or a life, in the grand scheme of things, “is a little blip.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons and Andy Newman
title: Lander Vows to End Street Homelessness for Mentally Ill People as Mayor
description: Brad Lander, the New York City comptroller who is running for mayor, announced a major plan to address homelessness after a series of violent attacks on the subway.
content: Brad Lander, the New York City comptroller who is running for mayor, unveiled his signature campaign issue on Monday: trying to end homelessness on the streets and subways for people with severe mental illness.
source.name: The New York Times

title: As L.A. Fires Rage, Pointing Fingers Rather Than Facing Facts
description: Readers urge public officials to take action on climate change rather than casting blame. Also: Teflon Don; the Gulf of America; treating schizophrenia.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sofia Quaglia
title: Are Smart Thermostats Worth the Money?
description: Here’s what to know about potential savings on your power bill, and the environmental benefits.
content: Smart thermostats first hit the market in the early 2010s as a way to strategically cut your electricity bill while still keeping your home nice and cozy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Dementia Cases in the U.S. Will Surge in the Coming Decades, Researchers Say
description: By 2060, new dementia cases per year could double to one million because of the growing population of older Americans, a study predicts.
content: The number of people in the United States who develop dementia each year will double over the next 35 years to about one million annually by 2060, a new study estimates, and the number of new cases per year among Black Americans will triple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Biden Administration Adopts Rules to Guide A.I.’s Global Spread
description: New rules aim to keep advanced technology out of China and to ensure that cutting-edge artificial intelligence is developed by the United States and its allies.
content: The Biden administration issued sweeping rules on Monday governing how A.I. chips and models can be shared with foreign countries, in an attempt to set up a global framework that will guide how artificial intelligence spreads around the world in the years to come.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Say Yes to Gnocchi
description: Shelf-stable gnocchi shines — in all its plump, chewy glory — in my new recipe for sheet-pan gnocchi with sausage and peppers.
content: The latest pantry staple in my weeknight rotation is shelf-stable gnocchi, and no one’s more surprised about that than I am. I’ve only infrequently had enough time and energy to make gnocchi from scratch, and when I’m too pressed, I generally rush right past those long-keeping vacu-packs on my way to grab the fresh stuff from the refrigerator aisle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alvaro Bedoya
title: I Work at the F.T.C. I Know What Is Killing Local Groceries.
description: The Federal Trade Commission’s decision to stop enforcing the Robinson-Patman Act is killing grocery stores in low-income communities.
content: Swaths of America have been hollowed out. Some people look at boarded-up shops in small towns and some urban centers and think: They just couldn’t compete. As an antitrust enforcer, I have a different reaction: Maybe we missed something.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: A Couple That Gets Dressed Together
description: Both are fans of relaxed silhouettes.
content: The billowy ensembles of Lindy Reyes, left, and Andre Reyes drew my gaze as I passed the couple on Mulberry Street in Manhattan on a Saturday in late December. The Reyeses, who were visiting New York City from Singapore, were in a line of people waiting to enter the Aimé Leon Dore store in NoLIta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chozick
title: Los Angeles Is Being Crushed Under the Weight of Inaction
description: At this point, we’d take concepts of a plan.
content: We got the evacuation alert on Wednesday night. The fire came out of nowhere and threatened to sweep through Hollywood. I pulled our son out of the bathtub. We rushed into the car and drove north, past two other fires, through smoke and sirens, gridlock and chaos, flames on the horizon in all directions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Toobin
title: How the Dream of School Integration Died
description: A powerful new book by the law professor Michelle Adams recounts the failed effort to integrate Detroit’s schools and the case’s relevance today.
content: Michigan prohibited segregation in public education decades before the Supreme Court did the same for the nation in Brown v. Board of Education in 1954. Yet nearly 20 years after Brown, the public schools in Detroit remained almost totally segregated. The story of how that happened, the failed effort to change it, and the implications for public education and civil rights today is the subject of Michelle Adams’s splendid new book, “The Containment.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noah Weiland
title: Melania Trump Says She Plans to Be at White House Full Time
description: Mrs. Trump did not immediately move in to the White House when her husband was inaugurated in 2017, but she said the second stay was going to be more routine. “I already packed,” she told Fox News.
content: Melania Trump, the former and incoming first lady, said in an interview broadcast on Monday that she planned to live and work full time in the White House during Donald J. Trump’s second term, addressing speculation about whether she would be a regular presence in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Biden’s Push to Cancel Student Debt Surpasses 5 Million Borrowers
description: With Monday’s authorization and 27 previous ones, the Biden administration has forgiven over $180 billion in student loans, even as its larger policy vision never took root.
content: The Education Department announced on Monday that it had canceled student loans for more than 150,000 borrowers, bringing the tally of Americans whose loans were forgiven under President Biden to over five million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Ivor Prickett
title: Greenland to Trump: We’re Not for Sale but Let’s Talk Business
description: The prime minister said that while Greenlanders do not want to become Americans, “the reality is we are going to work with the U.S. — yesterday, today and tomorrow.”
content: Greenland is ready to talk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: Egg Prices Are (Still) Up. Here Are 5 Easy Substitutes.
description: No one ingredient can replace everything an egg can do in a recipe, but these easy replacements come close.
content: Let’s be honest: There is no perfect substitute for eggs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: acerbic
description: This word has appeared in 73 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word acerbic has appeared in 73 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 8 in the obituary “Steve Albini, Studio Master of ’90s Rock and Beyond, Dies at 61” by Ben Sisario:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Texas Man Is Charged With Stalking Caitlin Clark
description: Prosecutors said the man had sent “sexually violent” messages to the Indiana Fever star and had traveled to Indianapolis to be closer to her.
content: A Texas man who prosecutors say sent a series of threatening and sexually explicit messages to the basketball star Caitlin Clark and traveled to Indiana to be closer to her has been charged with stalking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Have Americans Ever Really Been Healthy?
description: Medical historians say that the phrase “Make America Healthy Again” obscures a past during which this country’s people ate, smoked and drank things that mostly left them unwell.
content: “We will make Americans healthy again,” Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has declared. A political action committee that has promoted Mr. Kennedy, President-elect Donald J. Trump’s pick for health and human services secretary, says his movement is “igniting a health revolution in America.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: Why Do TV Title Sequences Have So Much … Stuff?
description: A visual style originally meant to make TV series appear epic and distinctive has become awfully familiar
content: Have you noticed that there’s a lot of stuff on TV lately?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 583
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Jan. 14, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, Delays Premiere of Netflix Show Because of Wildfires
description: She asked the streaming service to push back the release of her new series, “With Love, Meghan,” which pays tribute to the beauty of Southern California.
content: Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, has postponed the premiere of her new Netflix show, “With Love, Meghan,” because of the California wildfires, the streaming service said in a statement on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Elon Musk Is an ‘Evil Person,’ Steve Bannon Says
description: The comments highlighted rifts within the U.S. right wing and between two men who have been influential advisers to President-elect Donald J. Trump.
content: Stephen K. Bannon has launched a stinging attack on Elon Musk, calling him a “truly evil person,” in comments that deepen hostilities between two men who have been influential advisers to President-elect Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye and Lauren Hirsch
title: American Competitor Signals Possible New Bid for U.S. Steel
description: The company’s renewed interest comes after the Biden administration blocked Nippon Steel from acquiring the onetime American powerhouse.
content: A possible new takeover bid for U.S. Steel emerged on Monday, teeing up more turmoil over the once-dominant company’s future after President Biden’s decision to block its acquisition by a Japanese company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: It’s Not Only Trump We Have to Worry About
description: It’s way too soon for ideological score settling.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, I feel heartsick watching the images coming out of Los Angeles. Lives, homes, businesses, landmarks, neighborhoods — charred, destroyed, vanished. I know there was bound to be a political dimension to this and a lot of blame to throw around, but this should be an occasion for unity of purpose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Moises Velasquez-Manoff
title: Some Raw Truths About Raw Milk
description: Despite the serious risks of drinking it, a growing movement — including the potential health secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. — claims it has benefits. Should we take them more seriously?
content: Thousands of years ago, after domesticating cows and other ruminants, humans did something remarkable: They began to consume the milk from these animals. Scientists consider mammalian milk to confer a tremendous evolutionary advantage because it allows mothers to feed immature offspring with food well tailored to their needs. With the advent of dairying, humans inserted themselves into this ancient relationship between ruminant mothers and their offspring, diverting this source of nutrition into their own bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Tuesday Briefing: Death Toll Rises in L.A. Fires
description: Plus, what’s going on with TV credits?
content: A forecast of rising winds yesterday threatened the progress that firefighters had made to contain the destructive wildfires in Los Angeles. At least 24 people were reported to have died, and at least 16 people were missing in the areas of two of the blazes. Follow our live coverage here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Troops Captured by Ukraine Provide Rare Glimpse Into North Korea’s Military
description: Ukraine’s president released a video of the two soldiers being interrogated, revealing they knew little about the war they were sent to fight in.
content: One young soldier from North Korea said he didn’t know where he was fighting when he was sent from his isolated homeland to the frontline of the war between Russia and Ukraine. When asked whether his parents knew where he was, another North Korean soldier shook his head.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Schools Gear Up for a Threat to Immigrant Children
description: Donald Trump has said he will deport migrant families. New York City schools have a protocol for what to do if ICE agents show up.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at how the city’s public school system is preparing for the ways President-elect Donald Trump’s promises to deport immigrants could affect students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul A. Offit
title: Don’t Call Kennedy a Vaccine Skeptic. Call Him What He Is: A Cynic.
description: My job is to ask tough questions of vaccine makers. That’s not what he is doing.
content: The news media labels Robert F. Kennedy Jr. a vaccine skeptic. He’s not. I’m an actual vaccine skeptic. In fact, everyone who serves with me on the Food and Drug Administration’s vaccine advisory committee is a vaccine skeptic. Pharmaceutical companies must prove to us that a vaccine is safe, that it’s effective. Then and only then will we recommend that it be authorized or licensed for use by Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: How Lagging Vaccination Could Lead to a Polio Resurgence
description: In its original form, the virus survives in just two countries. But a type linked to an oral vaccine used in other nations has already turned up in the West.
content: Most American parents hardly give thought to polio beyond the instant their child is immunized against the disease. But there was a time in this country when polio paralyzed 20,000 people in a year, killing many of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: The Book So Helpful That the Eagles’ A.J. Brown Read It During a Game
description: What made the N.F.L. star open “Inner Excellence” by Jim Murphy as the action continued? “I like to read.”
content: The N.F.L. playoff game was still going on, mind you, while the Philadelphia Eagles star receiver A.J. Brown was engaged in some behavior you seldom see on a football sideline.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ismaeel Naar
title: In an Upended Mideast, Trump Faces a New Divergence With Old Allies
description: While major ruptures are not expected, Gulf states are urging a tougher stance on Israel and a softening toward Iran, positions that differ greatly from the president-elect’s first term.
content: When Donald J. Trump was last president of the United States, the wealthy monarchies of the Persian Gulf had a mostly harmonious relationship with his administration. As Mr. Trump prepares to return to the White House, the leaders of those Gulf countries have generally welcomed him back.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Jan. 12, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Jan. 12, 2025.
content: An article this weekend on Page 14 about some of the music industry’s most respected and consistently employed roadies, instrument technicians and live sound people being well into their 60s and 70s misstated who recently retired, at 69. It was Lorne Wheaton, not Dallas Schoo. It also misstated the name of a musician. She is Steph Paynes, not Payne.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Even Adults May Soon Be Vulnerable to ‘Childhood’ Diseases
description: Outbreaks among the unvaccinated are a predictable consequence of falling immunization rates. But even vaccinated adults may be vulnerable to some illnesses.
content: There were more than 32,000 cases of whooping cough in 2024, the highest tally in a decade. In California alone, the disease struck 2,000 people between January and October last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz and Cecilia Kang
title: OpenAI Courts Trump With Vision for ‘A.I. in America’
description: The maker of ChatGPT hopes to spur investment from the Middle East and avoid strict regulations on the development of new technologies.
content: In December, Sam Altman, OpenAI’s chief executive, donated $1 million to President-elect Donald J. Trump’s inaugural fund, joining a number of other tech executives who are working to improve their relationships with Mr. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: A Full Moon, a Bold Mars and a New Comet Brighten January’s Skies
description: On Monday night you may have a chance to witness the moon obscuring the Red Planet at its brightest, as well as a comet’s closest approach to the sun.
content: The first full moon of the year will glide through the sky on Monday night. For lucky stargazers in some parts of the world, it will also pass in front of the more-brilliantly-red-than-usual Mars in an event known as a lunar occultation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Trade Surplus Reaches a Record of Nearly $1 Trillion
description: China’s vast exports in 2024 exceeded its imports on a scale seldom seen anywhere except during or immediately after the two world wars.
content: China announced on Monday that its trade surplus reached almost $1 trillion last year as its exports swamped the globe, while the country’s own businesses and households spent cautiously on imports.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Enron Announces Return. Turns Out, It Was a Stunt.
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, January 13, 2025.
content: “The nuclear egg is 100 percent real.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Fuller, Mike Baker, Blacki Migliozzi, K.K. Rebecca Lai and Jonathan Wolfe
title: This Is Where the Palisades Fire Started
description: In the hills above Pacific Palisades, there is crime scene tape and scattered debris, clues to what may have caused the initial fire that eventually raged through thousands of structures.
content: The ridge high above Los Angeles is filled with clues. There are shattered pieces of electrical equipment, and a grove of madrone blackened by fire. Police tape is strung around one section of the sandy soil, now mixed with ash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum
title: Lebanon Names Nawaf Salam, a Diplomat and Jurist, as Prime Minister
description: The selection of Mr. Salam was seen as a blow to Hezbollah, the Lebanese militant group and political party that has acted as the real power in Lebanon for decades.
content: Lebanon’s fractured Parliament named Nawaf Salam as prime minister on Monday, handing the country’s political reins to the prominent diplomat and international jurist as Lebanon emerges from a devastating war and attempts to recover from a dire economic meltdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Paris
title: Falling Child Vaccinations
description: U.S. vaccination rates against once-common childhood diseases are falling.
content: After years of holding steady, American vaccination rates against once-common childhood diseases fell during the coronavirus pandemic and continued to drop for much of the past four years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: With South Korea in Crisis, Eight Justices Will Decide President’s Fate
description: The Constitutional Court, an arbiter in a polarized nation, is about to consider whether Yoon Suk Yeol’s impeachment for declaring martial law was justified.
content: For six weeks, South Korea has lurched through its worst political crisis in decades, throwing the resilience of the country’s democracy into question. On Tuesday, it takes the biggest step toward a resolution, when the Constitutional Court begins deliberating whether to remove or reinstate the country’s impeached president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Oscar Nominations Are Postponed Again Because of Wildfires
description: To give affected members more time, the academy extended the voting through Friday and will unveil the results Jan. 23. The nominees luncheon was canceled.
content: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has again postponed its nomination announcement in response to the fires that are still raging throughout Los Angeles. It also canceled its annual luncheon, which was set to be held on Feb. 10.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Strong Winds Threaten to Intensify L.A. Fires
description: Also, traffic eased after New York began congestion pricing. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Forecasters are expecting winds in Los Angeles to pick up late tonight and remain heavy over the next two days, a development that could reverse some of the hard-fought gains that firefighters made over the weekend. In anticipation, fire crews were deployed to at-risk areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Searches Continue for Nearly Two Dozen Missing in the Fires
description: As of Monday morning, the official number of missing persons included 17 in the area of the Eaton fire near Pasadena, and six in the Malibu area near the Palisades fire.
content: At least 23 people were still missing in the Palisades and Eaton fires on Monday, nearly a week after deadly fires broke out across Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jori Finkel
title: Ace Gallery Founder Is Sentenced to 24 Months in Embezzlement Case
description: Douglas Chrismas, who was found guilty last May on three counts of embezzlement from his gallery’s bankruptcy estate, is to report to prison on Feb. 17.
content: Douglas Chrismas, a pioneering art dealer who was convicted in May on three counts of embezzling from his gallery’s bankruptcy estate, was sentenced on Monday in federal court to 24 months in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley, Winnie Hu and Keith Collins
title: Less Traffic, Faster Buses: Congestion Pricing’s First Week
description: Early data from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority suggests that traffic has dropped around Manhattan’s core.
content: The first data for New York City’s new congestion pricing program shows that gridlock lessened in its initial week as fewer drivers traveled into the core of Manhattan, though traffic continued to be heavy in parts of the tolling zone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Promotes His Foreign Policy During His Final Week in Office
description: The president argued in a speech that he strengthened U.S. alliances during his four years in office and that America’s adversaries are weaker than when he took over.
content: President Biden kicked off his final week in office on Monday with a robust defense of his foreign policy, arguing in a speech that America had grown stronger on his watch and had “the wind at our back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen and Campbell Robertson
title: The Pitched Battles for Partisan Control in State Legislatures
description: As state legislatures convene, they face the same political polarization seen in Congress. Some are in near-deadlock.
content: In Minnesota, Democratic legislators are threatening to stay away from the state capitol this week to prevent Republicans from trying to claim control of the House of Representatives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Jack Healy
title: L.A. Wildfire Evacuees Scramble to Find Sleep in Cars, Shelters and Hotels
description: More than 90,000 people under evacuation orders are making do however they can.
content: Tens of thousands of wildfire evacuees in Los Angeles are now scrambling to find — and hold onto — temporary shelter, exacerbating the housing shortage in one of America’s least affordable cities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: In These 4 Novels, the Detectives Have Killer Instincts
description: Our columnist on the month’s best new releases.
content: A veteran best-selling legal thriller writer has a new book out this month featuring his signature defense attorney character. No, not that one — I mean James Grippando, who, over a 30-year career, has written 19 books starring the criminal defense attorney Jack Swyteck. In GRAVE DANGER (Harper, 320 pp., $30) Jack takes a pro bono client in an unusually perilous situation: She says she has fled Iran for Florida with her daughter because their lives would be in unfathomable danger if they stuck around. Her husband, who wants his child back, has sued for custody in Miami.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Liubov Sholudko and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: Battles Rage Inside Russia, With Waves of Tanks, Drones and North Koreans
description: Ukrainian soldiers are describing fierce clashes as Russian forces try to retake territory in the Kursk region that could be key in eventual cease-fire talks.
content: Five months after Ukrainian forces swept across the border in the first ground invasion of Russia since World War II, the two armies are engaged in some of the most furious clashes of the war there, fighting over land and leverage in the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,305
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, Jan. 14, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Confirmation Hearings Open in a Test of Trump’s Hold on Senate G.O.P.
description: Opposition to prospective nominees, along with time-consuming Senate rules, will slow floor action despite the Republican push for approval of some of President-elect Donald J. Trump’s picks as soon as Jan. 20.
content: The battle over President-elect Donald J. Trump’s cabinet choices will escalate this week with Senate confirmation hearings set for more than a dozen prospective nominees, who will face a barrage of questions from Democrats hoping to enlist Republicans in knocking at least a few out of contention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Oliviero Toscani, Driving Force Behind Provocative Benetton Ads, Dies at 82
description: A photographer and art director, he broke the boundaries of advertising in the 1980s and ’90s, embracing activism with images evoking AIDS and racial and sexual diversity.
content: Oliviero Toscani, an Italian photographer who used images of an AIDS patient and death row inmates to break the boundaries of fashion imagery as the creative mastermind of Benetton’s advertising campaigns, died on Monday. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: The Mothers on Broadway Are Finally More Than Monsters
description: Onstage, the flip-side of filial devotion has often been contempt. But a wave of forceful and multidimensional mothers suggests that may be changing.
content: The dramatic canon has always adored a nice, juicy perversion of motherhood — think the filicidal Medea; the incestuous Jocasta; even the ruthless Lady Macbeth, with her enduringly jarring mention of having “given suck.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Tim Arango, Will Jarvis, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: L.A.’s Private Firefighters, and U.S. Childhood Vaccination Rates Fall
description: Plus, remembering a civil rights Freedom Rider.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: Restaurant Wine Lists Are Getting Much Shorter
description: In an effort to engage their customers with wine, restaurants are trying friendlier, less intimidating ways to present their selections.
content: The wine list at Smithereens, a new seafood restaurant in the East Village, is shocking to say the least.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Lauren Hirsch
title: Talk Turns to ‘L.A. 2.0’
description: The governor of California has called for “a Marshall Plan” to rebuild the fire-ravaged city. But big questions loom about more ambitious and costly projects, including the 2028 Summer Olympic Games.
content: Angelenos can’t catch a break. Dangerous winds are expected to bear down on Southern California, putting homes and businesses from Ventura to San Diego County on high alert even as wildfires still rage around Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Kelly and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Trump Supporters Go All In for Pete Hegseth With Money and Coordination
description: Conservative organizations are targeting Republican senators, saying that they will pay a price if they do not back the president-elect’s choice for defense secretary.
content: As Pete Hegseth prepares for confirmation hearings, a coalition of outside groups is pressuring Republican senators to confirm him as President-elect Donald J. Trump’s secretary of defense — or face daunting political fallout it they do not.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: How Unauthorized Immigrants Help Finance Social Security Benefits
description: Undocumented workers often pay taxes that help fund programs like Social Security — even if they can’t collect from them in the future.
content: The Social Security Administration receives billions in free money each year from an unexpected source: undocumented immigrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: Moving N.F.L. Playoff Game Out of Fire Area Is a Logistical Challenge
description: Monday night’s game in Arizona between the Los Angeles Rams and the Minnesota Vikings is the first time the league has relocated a postseason game since 1936.
content: Matthew Giachelli got the call he anticipated on Thursday morning: The N.F.L. was moving the Rams’ playoff game to Arizona because of the wildfires raging in Los Angeles, and the league needed 200 gallons of paint pronto.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Clymer and Peter Baker
title: Stuart Spencer, Political Pioneer Who Helped Propel Reagan’s Rise, Dies at 97
description: One of the nation’s first campaign consultants for hire, he advised leading Republicans, including President Gerald Ford, but Reagan was his prized candidate.
content: Stuart K. Spencer, who as one of the nation’s first political consultants for hire took a so-called B-list actor named Ronald Reagan and helped him become governor of California and later president of the United States, died on Sunday at his home in Palm Desert, Calif. He was 97.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: New York Could Be the Next State to Limit Students’ Cellphone Use
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul on Monday signaled her plan to include related legislation in her budget proposal, saying she hoped to limit distractions during the school day.
content: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York on Monday announced her intention to limit access to cellphones in schools for students in kindergarten through 12th grade as part of her latest push to address children’s reliance on the devices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: After a Naming Contest, Cardea Joins the Celestial Ranks as a Quasi-Moon
description: The W.N.Y.C. science program “Radiolab” partnered with the International Astronomical Union to solicit nearly 3,000 submissions. The Roman goddess of doorways and transitions won out.
content: For thousands of years, Cardea has been known as the Roman goddess of doorways and transitions, a guardian of thresholds. On Monday, she joined the celestial ranks of fellow mythological figures like Mars, Venus and Andromeda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Erin Griffith, Jessica Cheung, Mooj Zadie, Nina Feldman, Eric Krupke, Mary Wilson, Lisa Chow, Patricia Willens, Marc Georges, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: Big Tech’s Big Bet on Trump
description: Silicon Valley billionaires are throwing their support behind the president-elect.
content: Big Tech’s biggest names are throwing their weight behind Donald J. Trump in the biggest possible way, first as candidate and now as president-elect.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Goodman
title: ‘Severance’, Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV This Week
description: The dystopian workplace drama returns after a nearly three-year hiatus. And a new series looks back at 50 years of “Saturday Night Live.”
content: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that are available live or streaming this week, Jan. 13-19. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon, Ronen Bergman and Isabel Kershner
title: Gaza Cease-Fire Deal Gains Momentum Ahead of Trump Inauguration
description: President Biden said negotiators appeared to be on “the brink” of an agreement to end the fighting and free the hostages held by Hamas.
content: High-level cease-fire talks appeared to be gaining momentum on Monday as Arab and American mediators pressed for an agreement to halt the fighting in Gaza and release hostages held by Hamas before President-elect Donald J. Trump assumes office on Jan. 20.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett and Glenn Thrush
title: Special Counsel Report on Hunter Biden Denounces President’s Criticism of Case
description: The report by the special counsel, David C. Weiss, criticized President Biden for making “baseless accusations” that threatened “the integrity of the justice system as a whole.”
content: David C. Weiss, the special counsel who spent years investigating Hunter Biden, criticized President Biden for making “baseless accusations” about his inquiry that threatened “the integrity of the justice system as a whole” in a final report made public on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: A New Age of American Interference in Europe
description: Elon Musk and MAGA are already disrupting the status quo, and Europe seems ill-prepared.
content: For the last decade or more, Europe’s governments have been trying to resist covert influence operations from adversaries like Russia and China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Kevin
title: Overlooked No More: Karen Wynn Fonstad, Who Mapped Tolkien’s Middle-earth
description: She was a novice cartographer who landed a dream assignment: to create an atlas of the setting of “The Hobbit” and “The Lord of the Rings.”
content: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich and Katie Robertson
title: News Outlets Take Unusual Steps to Prepare for Onslaught From Trump
description: Media organizations are preparing for what they fear will be a legal and political onslaught from the new administration.
content: Reporters and editors at national newspapers are increasing their reliance on encrypted communications to help shield themselves and their sources from potential federal leak investigations and subpoenas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Becky Ferreira
title: Mummies’ Ancient Tattoos Come Under Laser Focus
description: With a tool often used in the study of dinosaur fossils, scientists uncovered new details in ornate tattoos on the skin of members of the Chancay culture of Peru.
content: A culture flourished along the central Peruvian coast from about A.D. 900 to 1500. Called the Chancay, they left behind a wealth of cultural remains, including intricate tattoos that are preserved to this day on the skin of mummified individuals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nazaneen Ghaffar
title: How Bad Is the Forecast, and When Will L.A. Firefighters Catch a Break?
description: Another prolonged round of gusty Santa Ana winds was expected to intensify on Tuesday.
content: Los Angeles residents are facing another round of intense fire danger as gusty Santa Ana winds were expected to intensify once again over the next few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Baker
title: What the Fire Warnings Mean
description: From a red flag to a particularly dangerous situation, here’s how to understand some of the alerts going around.
content: If you’re tracking wildfires or the weather conditions that make them possible, you may have come across some terms you don’t recognize. Here’s what they mean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shayla Colon
title: Teacher Is Arrested After Threat Closes Schools in Montclair, N.J.
description: The police said a teacher at an elementary school who had recently been put on administrative leave was found in a “manic state” in Philadelphia and was apprehended.
content: Public schools in Montclair, N.J., were closed on Monday after a teacher at an elementary school threatened its principal on social media, the police said. Several hours later, the school district announced that the potential threat had been “neutralized.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Trump’s Reckless Greenland Comments Are Not a Joke
description: China and Russia are listening.
content: Late-night comedians have had a field day with Donald Trump’s musings about his administration possibly seizing Greenland and the Panama Canal. Hahahahahaha! That Trump — such a funny guy — you never know what will come out of his mouth next. Pay no attention. You know him, he’ll just say something else outrageous tomorrow!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: An Inauguration Watch Party Aimed at Celebrating Fossil Fuels
description: Harold G. Hamm, the founder of the Oklahoma-based Continental Resources, and other oil and gas companies stand to profit from Donald Trump’s energy policies.
content: Harold G. Hamm, the billionaire oil and gas executive who helped bankroll Donald J. Trump’s campaign and stands to profit from his energy policies, is hosting an exclusive fossil fuel industry celebration on Inauguration Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophie Bress
title: At This Ballet Company, the Priority Is Dancers’ Mental Health
description: Azara Ballet in Florida is a place where performers can just be themselves.
content: At Azara Ballet, dancers aren’t expected to make eye contact with the directors and choreographers. If company members need an impromptu break from the harsh stage lights during rehearsal, they take one. They also receive clear directions about hair and makeup well in advance of performances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Prolific Producer to Take Over Theater That Was Too Costly for Nonprofit
description: Seaview, whose buzzy shows include “Romeo + Juliet,” has seized a chance to have its own theater by taking over Second Stage’s former Off Broadway home.
content: In a vivid illustration of a rapidly changing real estate landscape for theaters in New York, the commercial production company that has brought Kit Connor, Rachel Zegler and George Clooney to Broadway is taking over a centrally located Off Broadway theater vacated by the nonprofit that long produced work there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Houndstooth Plaid and Pink Shoelaces
description: A pop of color punctuated a dashing assemblage of prints.
content: Antonio Francesco, 57, cut a dashing figure as he was walking to the Ralph Lauren store on Madison Avenue in Manhattan’s Upper East Side on Christmas Eve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Otis
title: A Frankenstein Filing Error: It’s Alive!
description: Mistakenly placed in Boris Karloff’s clippings folder, a photo of the actor Glenn Strange has since been published in error. Twice.
content: One of the actor Boris Karloff’s most lauded roles was his humanizing portrayal of a horror film progenitor: Frankenstein’s monster, based on the novel by Mary Shelley. He first played the monster, a nameless “creature” in Shelley’s novel, in the 1931 film “Frankenstein,” directed by James Whale.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachael Bedard
title: The New Alcohol Warning Is Not a Prescription
description: The surgeon general’s warning is information, not a prescription.
content: Surgeon General Vivek Murthy’s recent advisory that drinking alcohol raises the risk of cancer is something of a gamble. It’s a bet that telling people to do less of something they enjoy will be taken in good faith, and not as a politically motivated judgment of their lifestyle choices. It also exemplifies some perennial challenges in public health. Communicating about risk in an intelligible, actionable way to the public is hard to do without oversimplifying things. Helping policymakers and people decide what to do with the information is even harder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden Aides Warned Putin as Russia’s Shadow War Threatened Air Disaster
description: The White House scrambled to get a message to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia last year after U.S. intelligence agencies said a Russian military unit was preparing to send explosive packages on cargo planes.
content: After innocent-looking cargo shipments began catching fire at airports and warehouses in Germany, Britain and Poland over the summer, there was little doubt in Washington and Europe that Russia was behind the sabotage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Leslie Charleson, ‘General Hospital’ Actress, Dies at 79
description: Ms. Charleson played Dr. Monica Quartermaine, a cardiologist and family matriarch, on the daytime series for 46 years.
content: Leslie Charleson, who for nearly five decades played a dedicated cardiologist and passionate matriarch of a wealthy family on the ABC soap opera “General Hospital,” becoming one of the most enduring cast members in daytime television, died on Sunday at a hospital in Los Angeles. She was 79.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kari Molvar
title: It’s Dry Hands Season. Here’s What to Do.
description: Expert advice from a dermatologist, a ceramist and a hand model.
content: Beauty School, a series from T Magazine, answers common beauty questions with help from creative people who have become experts on the job. Sign up here to find us in your inbox once a month, and send any questions of your own to tmagazine@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kashmir Hill
title: Texas Sues Allstate Over Its Collection of Driver Data
description: The lawsuit accuses Arity, an Allstate subsidiary, of collecting data about people’s driving behavior through mobile phone apps, leading to increases in drivers’ insurance rates.
content: The State of Texas sued Allstate on Monday, accusing the insurer of illegally tracking drivers by way of their phones through a subsidiary called Arity that claimed to have the “world’s largest driving behavior database.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius and Anusha Bayya
title: Police Officer Shoots Man Who Called 911 to Report a Burglary
description: The victim, the police said, was carrying a knife. The shooting, which occurred after a five-second encounter, was under investigation.
content: It happened in five seconds. A police officer fired two shots at a 32-year-old man carrying a knife in a brightly lit hallway of a South Bronx building on Sunday evening, striking him in the torso.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: When to Report, and When to Help Out
description: Kellen Browning, a reporter based in San Francisco who has been covering the wildfires, was getting requests from evacuees, and he had a decision to make.
content: I had been in Pacific Palisades for only a few hours when I started receiving messages from evacuees asking about their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Should Grades Be Based on Excellence or Effort?
description: A guest essayist writes that too many students today wrongly expect to be rewarded for their efforts rather than the quality of their work. Do you agree?
content: What kinds of grades do you generally get in your classes? Are you satisfied with them? Do you think your marks have been accurate reflections of your learning?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and David W. Chen
title: In a Surprise, 76ers Say They Are Staying in South Philadelphia
description: The city had approved a plan for a new arena in a struggling part of downtown. But on Monday, the Sixers said a new venue would be built near their current one instead.
content: It looks like the Philadelphia 76ers won’t be leaving South Philly after all.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Jan. 13, 2025
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 13, 2025.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: Racing against more strong winds expected soon, firefighters in Los Angeles made progress yesterday in battling the area’s wildfires, which have killed at least 24 people and destroyed entire neighborhoods from the inland hills to the Pacific Coast. At least 16 other people have been reported missing. Read about the victims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquín
title: A Close Brush With Loss for a Community That Knows It Well
description: A 2008 fire gutted a mobile home park in the suburb of Sylmar. Last week, the Hurst fire came frighteningly close, and residents still haven’t let their guard down.
content: John Ward and his wife, Dawn Holder, were already packed and ready to go on Tuesday afternoon. The fire was then a 30-minute drive away, in the Pacific Palisades, and there were no evacuation orders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Jess Bidgood
title: Why Trump Turned to Manifest Destiny
description: Donald Trump has long sought to make anything he controls bigger.
content: President-elect Donald Trump is still a week away from taking office, but his musings about coercing Canada to join the United States while acquiring Greenland and the Panama Canal — declining at one point to rule out the use of military force in those two particular cases — have made for a surreal prologue to his second administration. It’s a fixation that has set world leaders on edge and forced congressional Republicans into the odd position of insisting that the incoming president is not planning to storm the Arctic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in California
description: A contemporary house in Idyllwild, a midcentury modern home in Palm Springs and a Queen Anne Revival in Napa.
content: This house, in the Tahquitz Shadow Estates gated community, has four bedrooms and three-and-a-half bathrooms and was designed by the architect Dennis McGuire. Elements of the landscape were incorporated into the structure, including boulders that protrude into the living spaces. The house is being sold fully furnished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Can I Dress Both Conservatively and Stylishly as a Young Person?
description: Our fashion critic offers a young reader debating whether modesty is compatible with current trends advice on navigating personal style preferences.
content: It’s true that “conservative,” at least when it comes to style, is often treated as something of a code word, or even a synonym, for “boring.” And the naked look has proved astonishingly resilient, not just on the red carpet and during award show after-parties, but also during urban summers everywhere, for a variety of reasons. And that tends to get a lot of attention because — shocking! (At this point, not really.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Paris
title: Childhood Vaccination Rates Were Falling Even Before the Rise of R.F.K. Jr.
description: The declines began with the pandemic, well before routine vaccines became part of the national political conversation.
content: The declines began with the pandemic, well before routine vaccines became part of the national political conversation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William B. Davis, Madison Dong, Judson Jones, John Keefe and Bea Malsky
title: Map: 6.8-Magnitude Earthquake Strikes Near Japan
description: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
content: View the location of the quake’s epicenter and shake area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: How Much Do You Know About These Controversial Classics?
description: Try this short quiz on literature from the first half of the 20th century that drew censorship challenges — and still does.
content: Try this short quiz on literature from the first half of the 20th century that drew censorship challenges — and still does.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Schupak
title: 35 Simple Health Tips Experts Swear By
description: They’re surprising, and surprisingly effective. And they’ll help you feel better every single day.
content: They’re surprising, and surprisingly effective. And they’ll help you feel better every single day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Meg Felling
title: Fires Continue to Rage Across Southern California
description: The wildfires have become some of the most destructive blazes in California history, razing neighborhoods and forcing thousands to evacuate their homes.
content: The wildfires have become some of the most destructive blazes in California history, razing neighborhoods and forcing thousands to evacuate their homes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Pena, Gilad Thaler and Mark Boyer
title: ‘They Barricaded Everything’: Living Inside an Evacuation Zone
description: Anthony Herrera never evacuated his Altadena home during the Eaton fire last week, and said he was told by the Los Angeles Sheriff’s Department that if he leaves now, he can’t return.
content: Anthony Herrera never evacuated his Altadena home during the Eaton fire last week, and said he was told by the Los Angeles Sheriff’s Department that if he leaves now, he can’t return.
source.name: The New York Times
